thread.title: China Investigating How Cockpit Windshield Blew Out of Sichuan Airlines Flight

author: Trefor Moss
title: China Investigating How Cockpit Windshield Blew Out of Sichuan Airlines Flight
text:
2 COMMENTS Chinese aviation authorities are investigating how the cockpit windshield of a Sichuan Airlines Airbus A319 jetliner blew out in midair, endangering the plane and those on board.
The plane was flying at 32,000 feet to the Tibetan capital Lhasa from the western city of Chongqing on Monday when its front right windshield became detached, exposing the cockpit to the freezing, low-pressure atmosphere outside.
Part of the flight control panel fell off, but the crew was still able to make an emergency landing in Chengdu, civil-aviation authorities said Tuesday. The co-pilot and one cabin crew member suffered minor injuries, but no passengers were harmed.
Chinese authorities said Airbus has assigned a team to provide technical support for the investigation into the cause of the incident.
Airbus didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment. The company has delivered nearly 1,500 A319s globally, according to its website.
Sichuan Airlines, a subsidiary of China Southern Airlines , the country’s biggest state-run carrier in terms of fleet size, confirmed that the aircraft had experienced a “mechanical failure,” but didn’t provide additional details.
Pictures circulated on social media showed the plane missing a windshield, though the aircraft appeared otherwise undamaged. The jetliner in question was less than seven years old, according to aviation website planespotters.net.
Sichuan Airlines, and Chinese commercial aviation in general, have a good safety record. Foreign pilots working in the country say Chinese airlines are extremely cautious about letting planes take off with even very minor technical issues, and that this focus on safety contributes to the chronic flight delays at Chinese airports.
Sichuan Airlines is primarily a regional carrier serving western China, though it has been adding long-haul international routes. In late 2016, it began flying directly to Vancouver, Canada from Zhengzhou, a city about 400 miles south of Beijing.
—Chunying Zhang contributed to this article.
